column1: Who will win the 2021 presidential election in Peru?
column5: ['A candidate from Acción Popular (Popular Action)', 'A candidate from Alianza para el Progreso (Alliance for Progress)', 'A candidate from Fuerza Popular (Popular Force)', 'A candidate from Partido Morado (Purple Party)', 'Another candidate', 'There will not be a presidential election in Peru before 1 October 2021']
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Elections and Referenda', 'Non-US Politics']
column11: Peru has seen a series of presidents come and go in late 2020 (Economist, CNN, Reuters). The presidential election is scheduled for 2021 with the first round of voting taking place on 11 April 2021 and a runoff scheduled for 6 June 2021 if needed (Peruvian Times).

column6: It’s virtually all done now. No path for Keiko Fujimori, other than claiming “the election was rigged.” The crowd odds of only .62 for Pedro Castillo are crazy at this point: https://twitter.com/ronaldcrossperu/status/1402466671793684480?s=21
https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2021/06/07/a-hard-left-candidate-has-a-slim-lead-in-perus-presidential-election

As is being said by some experts, the close vote count will lead to further instability and ungovernability and violence while the inevitable recount(s) will be challened, rechallenged, and by October (when the close of this problem ends) I suspect some things will come up and Keiko will be declared the winner.
Looking like Castillo now with the uncounted rural votes

Fujimori has a slight lead but Castillo is closing in and it sounds like most of the votes left are from rural areas where Castillo is favored. Predictit is heavily favoring Castillo, I assume they think the votes left to be counted will tip it in his favor.
https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/perus-castillo-falls-polls-suggesting-photo-finish-against-fujimori-2021-06-05/ If it's a photo finish, will they be taking it to the matte?

The second-round run-off for the Presidential elections in Peru has become a contest between Pedro Castillo (Peru Libre), a left -wing populist and Keiko Fujimori (Fuerza Popula), a conservative daughter of a disgraced former president (currently serving 25 years for death squad killings and corruption). Fujimori herself has spent more than one year in pre-trial detention accused of reciving illegal campaign funds and heading a criminal organisation. Covid has further impoverished the populace and given rise to the left-wing candidate. The establishment/elite in Peru are supporting Fujimori in fear of a Castillo presidency. The latest polls show a narrowing gap between the candidates with Castillo on 51.1% and Fujimori on 48.9% with another poll showing Castillo as dropping in support and Fujimori gaining.
https://news.yahoo.com/peru-election-race-tightens-week-152830304.html

Recent polls tightened a lot and Fujimori appears to be on the increase. It's a little way back but just under half of the votes in the first round were cast for centre right candidates who are I imagine likely to break for Fujimori, so on that basis we are also looking at a very close result. Also we have to bear in mind the earlier polls were way off the mark so there has to be a lot of error involved. I'm therefore only very weakly estimating a win for Fujimori based on some apparent upward momentum.
Latest FT coverage reports experts saying capital is flowing out of Peru at an alarming rate due to fear of "communist" leader...

New polls show both Fujimori's and Castillo's numbers have risen. Looking like it could go either way, as the difference is within the margin of error (https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-05-30/peru-election-race-tightens-a-week-before-polarized-vote).

Adjusting based on news of recent events creating bad publicity for Castillo, newest poll shows them neck-in-neck. Giving slightly more probability for Fujimori since I sense she has a little more momentum right now.
Polling is tight

Latest poll says Castillo is gaining over Fujimori (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-21/castillo-halts-fujimori-s-advance-in-latest-peru-runoff-poll). Still a toss-up with undecided voters, but given that both candidates are at the extreme ends of the political spectrum I'm assuming a 50-50 split.

It's amazing how consistently at least 15% of the electorate have either no idea whom to give their vote or intend to leave their ballot blank. This speaks for Pedro Castillo not being very reknowned among the people of Peru, the political class being disrespected in general for their lack of honesty, loss of reputation or management of public interest, or a great deal of resignation.
Narrowing, looks like Fujimori is catching up in the latest polls.
https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/peru-voter-simulation-shows-castillo-fujimori-now-neck-neck-2021-05-16/ stay tuned. or else.
Seems to be getting closer https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Peruvian_general_election#Electoral_polls

Neck and neck in the polls, with a lot of undecideds: https://encuestas.com.pe/encuesta-2da-vuelta-cit-11-mayo-2021/ There's also been a bit of a Keiko surge, so that has to be meaningful. Probably a slight advantage for her at this point?
Polling looks like it's narrowing a bit.

https://www.ipsos.com/sites/default/files/ct/news/documents/2021-04/6980121INF_V1_21Abr21.pdf Looks like voters are equal on why voting for each candidate on first place, agree with views. But very different for other reasons. Looking at the results of how strongly people would vote for each candidate it looks like a significant proportion of people are strongly against Keiko Fujimori and there are more definites for Pedro Castillo. If there are so many strongly against Fujimori this will make it hard for her to get the number needed, although it looks like a lot of people won’t vote so it may depend on who turns out. Plenty of time for the new guy Castillo to make a mess of things and the familiar lite of Fujimori to feel safer, even if people don’t like her.

The name of Castillo's "party" is Peru Libre = änother party... According to reports in LatAm MSM he is scheduled to debate Keiko in his hometown on Labor Day (tomorrow) but he is apparently too ill to do that. Keiko wants the debate held in Lima on Sunday 2 May on prime time TV so all of Peru can watch it. Link... https://en.mercopress.com/2021/04/30/peru-libre-candidate-pedro-castillo-hospitalized-with-respiratory-problems

The following link in Spanish from La Tercera in Santiago de Chile notes that Castillo is off the campaign trail for now, admitted to a hospital in Lima due to "respiratory problems" ... link https://www.latercera.com/mundo/noticia/candidato-presidencial-peruano-internado-de-urgencia-por-problemas-respiratorios/BBKDBRHWRNFIPCRBZCNIYROBBU/

I have doubts about the polling accuracy, but for now the polls do show Castillo with a huge lead. Note to self to look back at previous elections that went to a runoff and see what the polling looked like early on.

IEP poll shows Castillo has twice the support of Fujimori, and even if ALL the undecided voters voted for her, Castillo would still end up on top. Given the corruption in the country over the last few years and the charges against Fujimori’s father and herself, it’s unlikely the Peruvian public would have any appetite for a Fujimori presidency.
Castillo has a massive lead in the polls. I got this one wrong

I'm not going to put too much trust in the polls for the remainder of this question, the polls had some pretty big misses for the first vote. Polls might be more accurate with only two candidates though, and the only poll so far shows Castillo winning so switching to favor him slightly until we have more polling.
Polls were not overly helpful in predicting this market, and even though they are favouring "another candidate" by a decent margin now, I will handicap it slightly based on right vs left politics.

Well... Didn't see that coming! Interesting to learn lessons from that, the opinion polls until very shortly before the first round election were way off. Actually they fluctuated quite a bit so perhaps the lesson is to attribute less confidence to fluctuating polls? For now I'm resetting forecast slightly favouring Castillo as, (er...) the one poll on the two candidates is favouring him, but will update after further analysis. The key issue for me is who those who voted for others in the first round will move to.
Updating post first round. Will look to do something more in depth on the candidates through, but for now 2/3rds on plurality winner and 1/3rd on second
Castillo has wide geographic appeal and is a fresh face. Keiko will not make it.

To me it seems like for Peruvians the aversion to leftism will trump their aversion to Keiko. Castillo seemed to have the far left lane mostly to himself, while Fujimori had competition, so it makes sense that he would win the plurality in the 1st round. It seems like of the 2/3rds of voters who voted for the field in round 1, the majority are likely to break for Fujimori.
Going with the predictit odds for now until we see more polls.

Pedro Castillo is the "another candidate" ... you can read about him in English Wikipedia here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Castillo and in Wikipedia Spanish here https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Castillo
Reallocating no presidential election

Based on the latest report in Spanish by Peru daily El Comercio link https://elcomercio.pe/elecciones-2021/elecciones-2021-en-vivo-lunes-sigue-todos-los-detalles-y-declaraciones-tras-la-jornada-electoral-de-votacion-del-domingo-minuto-a-minuto-en-directo-online-elecciones-generales-peru-2021-resultados-onpe-jne-presidente-del-peru-congreso-pedro-castillo-keiko-fujimori-rafael-lopez-aliaga-hernando-de-soto-noticia/?ref=article&source=cintill For now left wing outsider Pedro Casillo, sometimes called the Evo Morales of Peru is the front runner. Who emerges as the candidate to challenge him remains to be seen, lots of backstabbing, backroom dealing and fake news for the next six months.
Looks like far left vs far right in the runoff

Pedro Castillo Should (Peru libre) go for the second round election and maybe De Soto (avanza pais) or Keiko (Fuerza popular) If It's Peru libre and Avanza pais, the answer is clear, it will be another candidate. If Keiko is going for the second round, she will not get enough support. She seem to have something like a " anything but Keiko effect". https://larepublica.pe/politica/2021/04/11/boca-de-urna-2021-en-vivo-resultados-de-la-onpe-conteo-rapido-flash-electoral-de-a-las-elecciones-2021-peru-atmp/?ref=lre https://gestion.pe/peru/politica/elecciones-generales-2021-segunda-vuelta-datum-escenarios-de-una-segunda-vuelta-como-se-comportan-las-preferencias-de-los-peruanos-noticia/?ref=gesr
Surprising results

Looking at article in Portuguese version of El Pais (Madrid) showing race is a almost "dead heat" based on latest IPSOS polling, I suspect that Keiko's crew will obtain what they need to gain more distance from the pack. If you read portuguese, here is link... https://brasil.elpais.com/internacional/2021-04-05/grande-incerteza-no-peru-com-cinco-candidatos-empatados-a-uma-semana-das-eleicoes-presidenciais.html#?sma=newsletter_brasil_diaria20210406
Latest polls not looking as good for Lescano

The second round will polarize. The only chance for Accion Popular to win is if they make it to the second round with Fujimori. If other than Fujimori from the right makes it to the second round that person will win. There is strong opposition to the left in Peru. Only the rejection of Fujimori is greater than that.
The incumbent is from the Purple party, so that might give the party an advantage. The pandemic and the unstable political situation are both reasons why there might not be elections at all.

Another poll from a solid pollster. Lescano gains a point vs. last time: https://gestion.pe/peru/politica/elecciones-generales-2021-encuesta-datum-lescano-mantiene-la-punta-y-crece-lucha-por-el-segundo-lugar-noticia/ Aliaga seems a bit more solid in 2nd place? Interesting that Lescano and Aliaga are also among the lowest in negative partisanship, while Fujimori's negative partisanship is off the charts.

Candidate Rafael Lopez Aliaga of the Renovcion Popular Party is creating attention for himself claiming that the Biden Administration has offered Peru Covid Vaccine. The foreign minister vehemently denies this, as this article in Spanish from El Comercio indicates. https://elcomercio.pe/politica/gobierno/cancilleria-niega-haber-recibido-ofrecimiento-de-gobierno-de-joe-biden-para-vacunas-contra-el-covid-19-rafael-lopez-aliaga-nndc-noticia/

Yonhy Lescano has recently risen conserably in the polls, now seems almost certain to get into the run off and also seems to have broad support across the political spectrum including voters who identify as centre right, he also has the lowest 'anti' vote (those who avow they will not support the candidate) of the candidates. I have put Keiko Fujimori down as her poll ratings have fallen and she is a polarising figure, unlikely to win against Lescano who has broader support. Another candidate encompasses George Forsyth who is currently disqualified but could appeal, poll ratings have dropped considerably but it could simply be that respondents assume he won't be allowed to stand so he could have a big bounce if he is officially reinstated. Others also encompasses Veronika Mendoza, and Rafael Lopez Aliaga whose poll numbers have risen but again us unlikely to command a majority in a run-off.

Slight tweaking based on IDICE poll just released, conducted 16-18 March: https://www.encuestas.com.pe/encuesta-presidencial-idice-19-marzo-2021/ Aliaga has a slight lead (and led it before with that pollster), although Lescano has nearly closed the gap.

Increasing for Yohny Lescano in light of his appeal to both left-leaning and conservative voters (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-peru-politics-lescano-exclusive/exclusive-peru-election-front-runner-vows-to-spread-mining-wealth-cut-natgas-prices-idUSKBN2B812M?il=0). The coronavirus pandemic, as well as recently exposed government corruption, will make his policies all the more attractive to voters.
Latest poll, with responses through the 16th: https://www.telesurenglish.net/news/Peru-Poll-Defines-Top-3-Candidates-for-Presidential-Elections-20210318-0019.html Lescano's highest poll yet.
Real roller coaster here. Reflecting the increase in popular action in the polls by pushing them up but also keeping other parties high just to reflect the uncertainty/volatility.

March polling: https://www.ipsos.com/sites/default/files/ct/news/documents/2021-03/situacion_politica.pdf https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Peruvian_general_election Looks like the traditional types of politicians are pulling ahead.

Slight adjustment, upon further research. The problem from the perspective of the other candidates is that Lescano beats everyone in the head-to-head questions. The far-right candidates have more voter enthusiasm, but there's no real ceiling on Lescano's votes, as a guy with high name recognition and a solid resume who basically takes the popular view on the contemporary issues.
Latest poll, commissioned by Peru's newspaper of record: https://elcomercio.pe/elecciones-2021/encuesta-el-comercio-ipsos-la-disputa-por-el-segundo-lugar-y-los-nuevos-escenarios-noticia/

As the presidential campaigning gains momentum prosectutors and opponents in Peru want to send Keiko back to jail big time. She is experienced at squiriming out of such situations in the past. Link in Spanish here via Santiago de Chile's La Tercera...
Decreasing for Popular Force because of corruption charges (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-11/peru-prosecutors-file-corruption-charges-against-keiko-fujimori)
-10 on popular force, Fujimori just charged with money laundering. https://www.reuters.com/article/peru-politics-idUSL1N2L92IO

https://gestion.pe/peru/politica/encuestas-yonhy-lescano-rafael-lopez-aliaga-george-forsyth-keiko-fujimori-lescano-repunta-mientras-lopez-aliaga-forsyth-y-fujimori-empatan-en-segundo-lugar-elecciones-2021-onpe-datum-noticia/ Lescano just had highest numbers ever, in poll just released. An "other," Aliaga (the Bolsonaro of Peru, in his words) is tied for a solid 2nd place with Fujimori. They both pretty much have the same voters Forsyth (also "another candidate") is also tied for third. Solid 4th is Mendoza.
Analysts are universal in saying Lescano of Popular Action is a high probability to make the runoff.
Looks like Forsyth is back in: https://ksusentinel.com/2021/03/06/research-leader-former-goalkeeper-receives-green-light-to-run-for-president-in-peru-3-6-2021-world/

According to recent polls (taken from Wikipedia, https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elecciones_generales_de_Per%C3%BA_de_2021), the Popular Action Candidate has gained votes. Chances increases given his more centered position in the political spectrum respect to his more near rivals. Keep an eye on the final list of candidates, it could change this probabilities

As far as I can tell, the race is pretty much even between Veronika Mendoza (Together for Peru), Rafael Lopez Aliaga (Popular Renewal), Keiko Fujimori (Popular Force) and Yohny Lescano (Popular Action). It's hard to tell what the undecided voters will do, but Keiko Fujimori's father on trial is likely to reduce the chances of a Popular Force victory, and her poll numbers haven't been increasing as steeply as the others. Also, with George Forsyth out of the race, his voters are likely to go to other liberal reformist candidates, which Keiko is not. Yohny Lescano is in the lead so far, but the margin of error is too large and too many undecided voters to say he will win with any degree of certainty. In any case, the election is expected to head to a runoff, and the undecided voters could prove instrumental in determining the final election results.

Drilling down a bit, Keiko (who has lived around half of her life in US) remains president of the K Party. And her "ruling tree" is intact. The role her American-citizen husband plays in her political life is usually not a part of coverge in US or Hispanohablante media. As a conservative populist she is a dealmaker and the deals that need to be made are with the rapidly expanding "extreme right wing" as this excellent opinion piece in Spanish in El Comercio of Lima explains... https://elcomercio.pe/opinion/columnistas/elecciones-2021-nuestra-extrema-derecha-por-martin-tanaka-noticia/ The notion of leftish-socialist broad front coalition suffers from decades of internecine warfare and bickering. A factor that is playing out again now in Brazil. The political fallout from the Odebrecht scandals still can hurt certain candidates. For those who are not aware, Odebrecht has changed its name to NOVONOR, but the media still call it Odebrecht in Peru, DomRep, Colombia, other nations where the scandals are still alive. Keiko understands "the attention economy" better than most.
Upon further research, dropping the odds for Alliance for Progress and Purple Party

I don’t understand the crowd odds. Usually I do and I don’t like to second guess. Does it seem likely that George Forsyth will be allowed back in? It does seem like a weird technicality that disqualified him
updated with latest poll (CPI)
Fight Club. “Nobody talks about fight club”

George Forsyth was leading in the polls, he has been disqualified but is apparently appealing so there is some chance that he will be successful and be reinstated. I previously gave him about a 60% chance of victory, I couldn't find any precedent for successful appeals against disqualification but in the 2016 election a couple of significant candidates were disqualified, don't know if they appealed or not but if they did they were not successful. Arbitrarily rated Forsyth's chance of successful appeal as 20% so have reduced 'other candidate' score' accordingly and increased Accion Popular and Fuerza Popular in line with this, moving slightly more towards FP as Keiko Fujimori's poll ratings seem to have rallied slightly since I last posted a forecast.

Forsyth has been disqualified, so I'm significantly dropping the "another candidate" category. The next best-polling party not listed here is Veronika Mendoza of Together for Peru, close to tied for third in latest polls. But there's still a lot of uncertainty and undecided voters, as well as 11% of voters still choosing Forsyth which will likely be distributed to others. So with that I'm favoring Popular Action and Popular Force right now based mostly on latest polling but also backed up by their stronger presence in parliament.

There will be a second tour, and in this case, George Forsyth should win, in regard of the recent polls. Guzmann - Morado, as well George Forsyth, is in a decline, Fujimori doesn't go anywhere, Lescano from Accion popular is in a rise.
https://www.ipsos.com/sites/default/files/ct/news/documents/2021-02/encuesta_nacional_urbano_rural_febrero_2021-intencion_de_voto.pdf
Updated for latest Ipsos polls.

With George Forsyth out of the picture, it's likely his voters will defect to other reformists. Yonhy Lescano (Popular Action) gained 4 points since Jan, as George Forsyth lost support, so it's possible he will benefit from Forsyth's misfortune and develop a lead. If no large changes in the current poll numbers occur, however, things will go to a runoff between Lescano and either Fujimori or Mendoza (of Together for Peru). This is why I'm still keeping some chance for Other.

+10% to Popular Action since people seem to be considering their candidate, Yohny Lescano, a viable alternative to George Forsyth, who is out of the running (https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/peru-greenlights-16-presidential-candidates-for-april-elections, https://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=64485&SEO=neoliberal-candidate-leading-in-polls-in-peru-loses-support). Her poll numbers have ticked up 4 points since January, and if George Forsyth is blocked from running, his voters may defect to her, giving her a strong lead. The reformist ideology of her party could present an attractive contrast to the more centrist Partido Morado (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_Action_(Peru)#Electoral_history, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purple_Party).

Adjusting up for Popular Action and Purple Party due to very surprising recent events (https://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=64485&SEO=neoliberal-candidate-leading-in-polls-in-peru-loses-support, https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/peru-presidential-candidate-confident-justice-will-prevail-after-election-exclusion). Popular Action, Purple Party, and Nationalist Party are all practically tied. Particularly notable increase in Popular Action candidate Yonhy Lescano's poll numbers (https://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=64485&SEO=neoliberal-candidate-leading-in-polls-in-peru-loses-support), so I'm giving her majority of points that Another Candidate loses from this news. Another Candidate is still a strong possibility because the Nationalist Party and Together for Peru are still in the running, and National Victory could also get Forsyth back in the running with an appeal to JNE (https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/peru-presidential-candidate-confident-justice-will-prevail-after-election-exclusion). However, even if Forsyth is reentered, it is likely his reputation will be tarnished by the scandal.

I updated my table based on the latest polls in wikipedia, and based on the last five polls it's looking like another candidate is a strong possibility. That said I don't understand the confidence here. For one around 20% of voters appear to be undecided, and another 25% did not answer. So there's a lot of potential votes out there that we can't be sure about. For another, even if we assume that George Forsyth of National Restoration is guaranteed to go to the runoff, his competitor seems very much up in the air. The next 6 best-polling parties range from 3.78% of those polled to 5.84% in the last five polls. I would imagine the margin of error on the poll encompasses that range. And 3 of the 6 are their own buckets outside the "another candidate" bucket, and the ones with their own buckets actually hold seats in parliament, which leads me to believe they're likely to be better recognized and may pull more of the undecided voters. Alternatively they could be more hated and pull fewer of the undecided voters, hard to say.

Based on current polling Forsyth is almost certainly going to get into the run-off but almost certainly not an outright victory so outcome depends on who other run-off candidate is. Recent opinion polls and Congressional election results suggest Fujimori unlikely. Accion Popular came top in Congress elections but only on about 10% of the vote and recent polling gives Lescano about 7%, I have given 40% chance of coming second and 40% of beating Forsyth in a run-off, giving 16%. Alianza para el progress second in Congress but getting slightly less support, have estimated at 30% of second place in first round and 30% in run-off. Purple Party I suspect unlikely to beat Forsyth in a run-off because Forsyth would I think appeal to supporters of more right wing candidate who in Forsyth-Guzman contest would not have a natural candidate. Some potential 2nd place are "others" https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Peruvian_general_election https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Peruvian_parliamentary_election
Popular Action and Alliance for Progress seem a long way behind in the polls. Popular force and Purple Party tied with about 3 others for second place and George Forsyth leading.
Updating as polls come in.

- 7 Fujimori Just before the election, Keiko Fujimori's father will be in court. Also, Keiko Fujimori said that she will apply a pardon for her father. Two measures that doesn't look good for Keiko. https://larepublica.pe/politica/2021/01/26/audiencia-por-esterilizaciones-forzadas-se-reanudara-el-lunes-1-de-marzo/ https://larepublica.pe/politica/2021/01/25/mendoza-sobre-alberto-fujimori-no-se-puede-indultar-a-un-violador-de-ddhh/ - 20 Cesar Acuna Peralta - Alianza para el Progresso ... not mention in the press, no trend for him, not enough twitter followers (only 61 k, Julio Guzman-Morado 427K, Keiko Fujimori- Fuerza Popular 1M, Vizcara- Somos Peru1,2 M, George Forsyth- Victoria 84 K)

Thirty eight years old, former football (soccer) star, from a family w diplomatic bckd... How do you spell George Forstyth... the model has worked elsewhere. Link... https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/this-soccer-star-could-be-perus-next-president/

- 1 Partido Morado +1 Another candidate ( George Forsythe - Victoria Nacional) Guzman have covid-19 https://larepublica.pe/elecciones/2021/01/22/julio-guzman-candidato-presidencial-del-partido-morado-dio-positivo-a-covid-19-pltc/
Some doubts about the election's date. https://larepublica.pe/politica/2021/01/23/rechazan-propuesta-de-martin-vizcarra-sobre-postergacion-de-las-elecciones/
+2% for George Forsyth maintaining the lead (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-peru-politics/perus-keiko-fujimori-says-would-pardon-father-if-elected-president-idUSKBN29N1HT)

I was a bit puzzled by the crowd forecast when I first forecast this. Seems much more sensible know more in line with my limited reading on the topic. Taking no election and another candidate from the consensus. Keeping purple where it is as their 2nd place seems slim and having the other as straighline.

Seems similar to the election where the well-known TV--star outsider Zelensky beat Poroshenko in Ukraine. The government is in tumult and the people want change. They will react well to George Forsyth because he's famous just like Zelensky was.
from 23 to 15 Fuerza Popular 0 to 8 Alianza para el Progresso, Martin Vizcarra
Popular Force has become extremely unpopular in Peru, having their seats in Congress reduced from 73 to 15 in 2020.

Given that there are 22 candidates and two of the leading candidates (Forysth and Mendoza) are not in the list of parties provided and one of those (Forsyth) has a commanding lead of around 10 points in most polls. It seems likely that a candidate from an unlisted party will win. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Peruvian_general_election

- 2 Fuerza Popular... it seem that there is a probe for miss Fujimori. Whatever the veracity about, it does'nt start well an election race. https://larepublica.pe/politica/2021/01/04/fiscal-perez-concluye-en-enero-investigacion-a-keiko-fujimori/
From polling average in December 2020:
it will be an independent candidate

With elections scheduled, public opposition to their postponement even from congressional incumbents (https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-peru-politics/head-of-perus-congress-assumes-presidency-vows-to-respect-election-timetable-idUKKBN27Q1XD), and Peru's coronavirus case rate likely to decrease further as Spring arrives and a vaccination campaign begins, it seems unlikely that there'll be no election before the 1st October. But a postponement/cancellation can't be ruled out in such a crisis, so a 5% chance seems reasonable.

With the legislators impeaching a popular president and installing an unpopular one who lasted a matter of days, the country must be totally disillusioned with its political class with calls for constitutional reform. 32% of people in a December 2020 survey said they would not support any candidate. The polls are showing George Forsyth to be leading with just 18% support while the purple party candidate (same as Sagasti) is only at 8%. Therefore the indication at this stage would indicate ‘another candidate’ to be most likely for a) popularity and b) to vote against the political elite.
No strong front runners - think larger political currents across the world and complete disgust with incumbent politicians mean an outsider has a better chance than in a normal cycle.

National Restoration (George Forsyth) has the most support. The big question is how much consolidation could happen by election time. It's hard to say what parties might drop out and put their support behind another candidate, or if that will even happen at all. Hard to be confident on any of these. Some of the parties with little support have larger representation in parliament, so it's difficult to determine if the polls are missing some support for these candidates.
